quote.para: HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL BENEFITS.

answer.para: Mr.Watkins asked the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: What profits have been made by the various individual medical and hospital benefit societies since their registration under the scheme?
Where directors of such societies are paid honorariums or salaries, are they made known to the Minister?
If so, will he make this information available in his answer?

talk.start.para: . - The answers to the honorable member's, questions are as follows : -

item.para: Only non-profit-making organizations are eligible for registration under the National

question.para: Health scheme. When contributions received during a year exceed the amount of claims paid and the costs of management of the organization, the excess is set aside as a reserve to meet outstanding claims and to ensure that claims are met in adverse times as, for instance, in the event of an epidemic. These reserves have enabled some organizations to provide additional benefits to their contributors or to reduce the rates of contribution.

item.para: Societies are not required to furnish details of honorariums or salaries to directors. They are however required to ensure that the ratio of their total management expenses to contributions is not unduly high. Only organizations with a satisfactory record of economy in management have been registered.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that no check is made by the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia and similar organizations to test the accuracy of claims by ascertaining whether the medical treatment upon which the application is based was in fact received by the applicant?
Is it a fact that the Government's contribution to the cost of medical treatment is made payahle on the decision of the Medical Benefits Fund or similar organization in respect of each application ?
Is ita fact that payments made in respect of successful claimsbased on costs incurred in confinement cases represent less than one-third of the total amount expended by the applicant?

Are the Medical Benefits Fund and similar organizations obliged by law to publish annual balance-sheets and financial statements at more frequent intervals; if so, have they complied with this requirement?

talk.start.para: . - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows : -

item.para: Claims for benefits from medical benefits organizations must be accompanied by doctors' accounts setting out the date and the nature of each service and by receipts showing that the account has been paid. Where this evidence is considered insufficient to enable the claimant's benefits to be determined, an organization obtains further information from the contributor or from the doctor.

The total amount of Commonwealth benefit payable for each claim is determined by the organization in accordance with the schedules of benefits and in the light of instructions issued by the Department of Health. Where an organization is in doubt as to the benefit payable it refers the matter to that department tor direction.
No.

Medical benefits organizations are not required by law to publish annual balance-sheets and financial statements. The National Health Act requires each organization to furnish to the Department of Health a balance-sheet and revenue account for its medical benefits fund and hospital benefits fund. All organizations comply with this requirement. Under certain State laws, such as the Companies Act and the Friendly Societies Acts, organizations must furnish financial statements to State authorities.

talk.start.para: d asked the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that his department* is in possession of evidence which establishes that some members of the pharmaceutical and medical professions have been engaged in fraudulent practices in respect of the operation of the Commonwealth medical scheme, including the service provided for pensioners?

If so, will he have a statement prepared giving (a) the number of known offenders, (6) the number of prosecutions instituted, (c) the action taken in cases where no prosecution was instituted and [d) the number of successful prosecutions and the nature of the penalties imposed?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows : -

item.para: All suspected cases of fraud are referred to the Crown law authorities for advice as to whether prosecution should be instituted: Pharmaceutical chemists and medical practitioners have been prosecuted in all cases where such action was considered to be warranted by the Crown law authorities.

Fourteen pharmaceutical chemists have been convicted of offences under the national health legislation. In all cases fines were imposed. Two prosecutions were unsuccessful. Four medical practitioners have been convicted of offences under the national health legislation. In three cases a fine was imposed and in the other case the medical practitioner was sentenced to twelve months imprisonment. The agreement relating to the provision of medical services to pensioners was terminated in each case.

talk.start.para: d asked the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: To what particular classification of sufferers from tuberculosis is the Commonwealth tuberculosis allowance paid.?
When is a sufferer from tuberculosis, for the purpose of payment of the allowance, no longer regarded as being a public risk?

Is it a fact that in a great number of cases the Commonwealth tuberculosis allowance has been cancelled whilst the patient is still receiving treatment in a hospital or sanatorium and whilst the patient is deemed by his doctor to be still too ill for discharge?
Is it a fact that one of the prerequisites for the successful treatment of this ailment is to free the patient from worry?

item.label: a.
item.para: If so, is it a fact that in many cases where the allowance has been cancelled before a cure is effected, the patients' conditions have deteriorated?

Is it also a fact that in respect of the tuberculosis allowance, as with all other Commonwealth social service payments, instructions have been issued by the Government to departmental officers that the cases of all recipients are to be carefully perused with a view to cancellation, where possible, to reduce expenditure?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows : -

item.para: To sufferers from tuberculosis who are a hazard to public health, namely, those who are infectious or in serious danger of becoming so.
When he is no longer infectious and not in serious danger of becoming so, as to which the medical referees (the State Directors of Tuberculosis) have the widest discretion.
In no case has tuberculosis allowance been withdrawn from a sufferer possessing the qualifications specified in No. 1 above.

Yes, and free hospitalization and a generous tuberculosis allowance are provided to that end. But a sufferer who is not a hazard to public health is no more entitled to a special allowance than are sufferers from other disabling diseases.
No.

No. On the contrary, all departmental officers are aware of the Government's desire that the tuberculosis allowances scheme should be administered with the same sympathy and understanding as the scheme of social service benefits.
